I don't think ppl give animals the credit the deserve like they don't know those r not their kids... I had a mare once and she always tried to steal other mares babies she'd call them over and end up getting in trouble with their moms... She knew they were not hers. She just loved babies. Baby horses. And my gelding. He took over my other mares parenting duties. She spent less time being a parent than my gelding lol. That mares foal spent more time playing and having my at the time 17 18 year old gelding dote on him. When the little fella was weaned the first day he tried to nurse from my gelding's sheath and my gelding put a leg back like the foals mom did and just let the little weanling figure out nothing was happening and then my weanling never tried that again. He guarded the little guy too. He wouldn't let any other horses get to close. He would chase them away even if the weanling was the one that initiated the encounter. He raised that weanling for the next 3 years and now he's a 4 year old stallion with an amazing calm mind thanks to my gelding, raising him so well. They r still pastured and stalled right enxt to each other and nicked to each other in a hello when one comes or goes. 🥰 Animals know, they don't always have to even be female or have just had a baby, they just have big hearts like any human would sometimes. After all, in the end all  we r are animals too. ❤️

I have a cat with kidney disease, and I treat him like a son, worry about him when I go to the doctor or to the store, am trying every supplement I can to try to heal him, ones that I can't really afford. He's had health issues for most of his life, so I even favored him over another who I actually lost to cancer back in 2019. That cat hid his pain. The one I care for now never did, so he got babied more.

I do have a daughter, and she jokes that I love animals more than people, and I probably do. I don't get to see her or my 6 grandchildren very often, and there's still a mother inside me, one that fears losing her son. He gives me purpose and that unconditional love that humans have never offered me.

I mean... Evolution doesn't care if you survive or not, it just happens, and the individual living being and/or the entire species are better of because of it (or not, in which case the mutation isn't kept by way of natural selection), so expecting an animal to not care for other animals' youngs seems to imputate our view on nature to the animals themselves ("nature is cruel, the species that perform best physically get to survive" etc) whilst such cases of solidarity help keep the species alive and even let it prosper as well; animals with highly developed social skills tend to perform better as a species, if not on an individual level. Something akin to what we call "empathy" when referring to our relations with other humans can help a species to prosper, and thus get "selected for" just as well. Especially if we take into account that not all behaviour is inscribed in the genes, and that animals teach their young tricks that they themselves have learned to be useful from their own parents, and during their lifetimes.
I feel like being surprised by such things, and searching for a "rational" decision making process, or straight up searching for "dysfunctionalities" in the animal's behaviour, is mostly a case of imputating a strict reading on how evolution is "supposed" to work, and thusly gives place to a distortion based on our urbanized vision on "the wild".
In a way its not so different from imputating human behaviour on animalia; an otter doesn't "love" its young, because love as term is for human relations; we can not say with certainty or precision that an otter "loves" its young. The same way we can't say that it is "in competition with other members of its species"; while trying to minimize distortion on reality caused by our human understanding of things, we risk falling right back into it, only on the other end of the spectrum.

"The Selfish Gene" theory on evolution is compelling. But often it takes a lot of stretching to make it fit the facts.

Perhaps we would be better off simply closing our eyes to examples like this? After all, simply saying, "Greed is good." works for Wall Street Bankers. Isn't that enough proof for science? [satire]

I don't understand why an animal adopting another's offspring doesn't make sense from an evolution standpoint - wouldn't evolution favor animals who are concerned with survival of their species rather than direct descendant? Like, think of 2 animal types - 1 in which the subjects are often more "selfish" and only look after their own and don't care if their neighbors don't make it and 1 in which the subjects are helping each other and ensuring ALL offspring of their species make it, not just their own - wouldn't it stand to reason that the species most likely to survive and continue their lineage are the ones who are more adept to helping their species (rather than immediate family) flourish?
I'm no scientist and could be very wrong, but to me it seems like this shouldn't be the anomaly, but the norm.

Alloparenting is more specifically an evolutionary adaptation that facilitates the survival of both fauna and flora within a biome. These fantastic mechanisms have been observed for over a century. Even with the confines of a niche (pronounced properly as it sounds like "stich" not "steesh"). Wolves are very fascinating in their care of humans on occasion, but the bioenergetic efficiency is higher than other species so they likely can afford an extended family, as they have been known to raise humans of all creatures.

I have a black lab mix Negrita, that I rescued, that rescues other dogs. She goes out and finds them and brings them home. If I put food in her bowl she will direct the other dog to eat and won't eat it herself. She adopted a pit mix pup someone abandoned, we found that pup a home. Than she brought home an extremely emaciated boxer. She was skin and bones and had a broken, rotting back foot. I contacted a boxer rescue group and took her to another rescuer that was going to transport her. Then she brought home another lab, a male chocolate lab. He was abandoned after hurricane Maria when his owners left to the states. He still lives at my mom's with Negrita. She is pretty old now though.

We adopted two more cats recently. One was a year and a half older than our cat, and the other about 3 younger... The middle cat is mama. She snuggles the others and was a huge help in helping the older cat by providing emotional support after we had to remove her from her deceased owner's home. She adjusted quickly, and we often mimicked the middle cat's behavior.

Little cat was a baby who lost her mom that we had to bottle feed. She clung to me, because I fed her, but Middle cat was super playful and taught both of the adopted cats to be more gentle in play. I do remember her getting in the middle of a fight when older cat got aggressive towards little one.

Middle cat was spayed, too. (We have a huge stray problem here, and I don't want to add to it) I wonder if that bit about possibly having their own litter would still apply?

My Ecology and Evolution professor taught me about this concept when I was an undergrad. He told me to look at evolution as the fitness of an allele or in this case a concept called “inclusive fitness“. Sometimes animals will take care of cousins or even non-blood children because they have a certain chance to have the same alleles as them. This is seen in Belding’s ground squirrels with their alarm calls and the rule for this is called “Hamilton’s rule.” It changed the way I looked at evolution and made me enjoy the concept a lot more.

My dog, who loved swimming and diving underwater and catching fish, rescued a kitten who had been thrown in the lake and was the sole survivor. She brought him to shore and insisted we take him home, where she totally raised him and nursed him with her puppies, and taught her puppies to be easy on the kitten. She was very insistent on gentleness with the kitten as opposed to wrestling like crazy things with each other. As the kitten only knew dogs , he didn't know he could jump, climb, or anything cats need to do. So she found a random female cat, chased it into our yard about four or five times, and introduced it to her adopted cat. The female cat hated the dogs, hated the yard, hated the cat who thought it was a dog, but for god knows what reason, started pushing the dog-cat to do cat things. She chased him up a tree about 15 times and taught him how to get down. He had never climbed before, so he kept running to Shiela, my dog, to get this mean cat away from him. It was so damn funny to see these two moms teaching this cat to be a cat. She taught him to jump, she taught him to groom. She taught him how to be a cat. And she decided she liked dogs.

Something that wasn't clear here was whether there is any impulse for animals to preserver their own social group or even species.  It seems odd to me to minimize the drive to "pass on one's genes" to the individual.  I do think this drive exists, but couldn't there be layered drives?  If in a circumstance I can't work to pass on my genes, I'll work for the closest thing:  another member of my species.  We can expand this further and look into the maintenance of an ecosystem.  Robust ecosystems are good at preserving the individuals within them, which may be why we even find cross-species alloparenting.

Another great SciShow video!  Another thing to point out regarding alloparenting is that evolution affects ENTIRE populations (not just individuals), so more cooperative behavior (like alloparenting) is a win-win for the entire population of that species.  Just sayin'....

Im a rabbit breeder and rabbits do this too. For example I had 2 female's give birth last month but one female lost 2/3 of her babies so I had to foster the single baby to the other litter because they need the warmth of siblings in the nest to stay warm and survive. The other female doesn't notice and raises the foster baby as her own. You can switch baby rabbits around to different mothers and they would nurse them.

We have a picture of me and Rosa when we were both pups! I was born in Santa Cruz and we went to the aquarium a lot. I fell in love with Rosa, and actually got to watch her learn to swim!
The mention of cuckoos made me think of something I've wondered about for a while, namely, how does a cuckoo know it's a cuckoo if it's raised by a different bird?

I did a paper on this back in the day for school. My favorite animal was the Merganser a type of duck that loves rapids. Seriously, if you ever see one in rapids they use them like water slides, flying back up and going down them again and again. They adopt because in these turbulent rapids chicks are likely to be separated from the group. So if they all adopt lost chicks odds are their own offspring that get mixed up will survive as well.

Successful cuckoo birds are hilarious to watch. You see this tiny bird feeding its 2 tinier young and then this giant cuckoo youth like
"Mah! MAH!!! More hotpockets!!!"

i used to have a yorkie who was extremely maternal, i used to do rescue and so many pups were brought up by that little one, it did not matter if the pup was bigger than her she would still love them and look after them. she could bring round a terrified pup in no time. lol she would even teach them manners as they grew, her last pup, i still have, a huge alaskan malamute.  until the day momma died she could have this big brute lie on the floor and have her face washed.   momma took no arguments from unruly pups.   i miss her so much, never known another dog like her. 18 years she cared for every pup she saw, then one night just closed her eyes and never woke up. she never had her own litter, she had a few health issues, but she proved you don't need blood to be the greatest momma.

If a population has genes that make adults want to take care of all kids, not just their own, wouldn't that inherently strengthen the population by resulting in higher numbers of healthy adults, anyway? I mean, sure, on an individual level, it may not appear ideal, but at least once the gene has spread through the population, any one kid is significantly more likely to make it to adulthood and to produce its own offspring.
